Non-Profit Corporation Formed To Channel Aid to Panama
DOC.TEXT: A non-profit corporation has been formed to channel medical supplies and other emergency contributions to Panama, where fighting left thousands homeless and many wounded, an official said Sunday. ``AID To Panama'' has been designated as the official organization to receive funds and other contributions, said Carlos F. Rodriguez, Panama's newly appointed ambassador to the United States. ``Our task of rebuilding our beloved country has begun,'' said Rodriguez in a statement. ``However, urgent humanitarian needs are still unmet and all help is needed. We appreciate all offers of assistance from our American friends.'' Rodriguez said the need is greatest in Panama City, where a week of fighting has left an estimated 25,000 people homeless and care for the many wounded is urgent. Hospitals face dire shortages of all medical supplies, he said. Dr. Jose Trinidad Castillero, Panama's minister of health, has issued an urgent appeal for intravenous solutions, antibiotics, insulin, and anaesthetics. The shortage of blood is so severe, that doctors at Santo Tomas Hospital donated their own blood, Rodriguez said. ``AID to Panama'' is working with Catholic Relief Services and Direct Relief International, two groups organized to respond to international health care needs. Corporate donations of supplies and transportation already have been received but Rodriguez said individual cash donations are urgently needed. Checks and other contributions should be made to ``AID To Panama'' and sent to either: Catholic Relief Services, 209 W. Fayette Street, Baltimore, 21202; or, ``AID To Panama'' Sun Bank (Acct. No. 01-890-0114-0297), 777 Brickell Ave., Miami, Fla. 33131.
